Richardson's Extrapolation

Extrapolation

  1. What?
    • Extrapolation that is used to generate high-accuracy results while using low-order formulas.
    • Extrapolation can be applied whenever it is known that an approximation technique has an error term with a predictable form, one that depends on a parameter, usually the step size .
    • Suppose that for each number we have a formula that approximates an unknown constant , and that the truncation error involved with the approximation has the form,

      for some collection of (unknown) constants .
    • The truncation error is , so unless there was a large variation in magnitude among the constants

      and, in general,
      .
    • The object of extrapolation is to find an easy way to combine these rather inaccurate approximations in an appropriate way to produce formulas with a higher-order truncation error.
  2. Why?
    • We can combine the formulas to produce an approximation formula, , for with
      ,
      for some, again unknown, collection of constants .
      Then we would have
    • If the constants and are roughly of the same magnitude, then the approximations would be much better than the corresponding approximations.

  5. When to apply Extrapolation?

    Extrapolation can be applied whenever the truncation error for a formula has the form:

    for a collection of constants and when .

    The extrapolation is much more effective than when all powers of are present because the averaging process produces results with errors , with essentially no increase in computation, over the results with errors, .
